title: S Club 7 ‘in talks’ to Bring It All Back and reunite for 20th anniversary tour
text:
S Club 7 could be reuniting for a 20th anniversary show (Picture: Ilpo Musto/REX/Shutterstock)

If you were looking for an S Club Party in 2019, you might be in luck, with S Club 7 reportedly ‘in talks’ to reunite for a 20th anniversary tour.

The hugely popular band released their first song – fittingly called Bring It All Back – in 1999.

All members of the band – Rachel Stevens, Jo O’Meara, Hannah Spearritt, Tina Barrett, Bradley McIntosh, Jon Lee and Paul Cattermole – are reportedly keen to get the group back together, according to The Mirror.

A source close to the band revealed: ‘There is talks in between band members now about doing a reunion arena tour next year.’

‘A lot of the bandmates are up for it. It’s still early days but they are talking and fans may be in for a treat in 2020. It all makes perfect sense for a reunion celebrating 20 years of S Club 7,’ the source added.

Maybe the Spice Girls doing a reunion tour was inspiration?

S Club 7 could be getting back together for 20 year reunion tour (Picture: Gareth Cattermole/Getty Images)

Rachel recently revealed she would definitely be up for getting the band back together.

She told Lorraine Kelly: ‘We’re all over the place, but we did do a reunion tour four years ago.’

Beaming at the camera as she fondly recalled her time in the band, the mother-of-two added: ‘I would definitely do it again.’

‘I’m so proud of what we have done and achieved,’ she added.

She spoke about how great it would be to go into it now that they’re all a little bit older, and confessed that she does meet up with her S Club buddies every now and again.

S Club 7 had hits like Don’t Stop Movin and Reach, but they ran out of steam when Paul decided it was time for him to ‘move on’ from the band in 2002.

In April 2003, the band officially split up, but reunited 11 years later for a special BBC Children in Need telethon.

They went on to do a reunion tour in 2015.

Reps for S Club 7 were approached by Metro.co.uk for comment.
